      • MurmurHash3_x86_32_direct

        public static int MurmurHash3_x86_32_direct(MemoryAccessor mem,
                            long base,
                            int offset,
                            int len)
        Returns the MurmurHash3_x86_32 hash of a memory block accessed by the provided MemoryAccessor. The MemoryAccessor will be used to access int-sized data at addresses (base + offset), (base + offset + 4), etc. The caller must ensure that the MemoryAccessor supports it, especially when (base + offset) is not guaranteed to be 4 byte-aligned.

      • MurmurHash3_x64_64

        public static long MurmurHash3_x64_64(byte[] data,

                      int len)

      • MurmurHash3_x64_64_direct

      • MurmurHash3_x64_64_direct

        public static long MurmurHash3_x64_64_direct(MemoryAccessor mem,
                             long base,
                             int offset,
                             int len)
        Returns the MurmurHash3_x64_64 hash of a memory block accessed by the provided MemoryAccessor. The MemoryAccessor will be used to access long-sized data at addresses (base + offset), (base + offset + 8), etc. The caller must ensure that the MemoryAccessor supports it, especially when (base + offset) is not guaranteed to be 8 byte-aligned.

      • hashToIndex

        public static int hashToIndex(int hash,
              int length)
        A function that calculates the index (e.g. to be used in an array/list) for a given hash. The returned value will always be equal or larger than 0 and will always be smaller than 'length'. The reason this function exists is to deal correctly with negative and especially the Integer.MIN_VALUE; since that can't be used safely with a Math.abs function.
        Parameters:
        length - the length of the array/list
        Returns:
        the mod of the hash
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if mod smaller than 1.

      • computePerturbationValue

        public static int computePerturbationValue(int capacity)
        Computes the key perturbation value applied before hashing. The returned value should be non-zero and different for each capacity. This matters because keys are nearly ordered by hashcode so when adding one container's values to the other, the number of collisions can skyrocket into the worst case possible.

        If it is known that hash containers will not be added to each other (will be used for counting only, for example) then some speed can be gained by not perturbing keys before hashing and returning a value of zero for all possible capacities. The speed gain is a result of faster rehash operation (keys are mostly in order).
